    <li> We should start off with a little terminology. In this case, the lowest grade. The misconception is that with an Escali you&#x27;re getting a quality badger brush at a fraction of the price, but you&#x27;re really not.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;What&#x27;s wrong with low-grade badger hair? Absolutely, and I did for months before I learned of much better options in a comparable price range. You will get by, until you learn of what can be had, and then you won&#x27;t go back.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;What should you look for instead? Boar hair. While boar hair isn&#x27;t quite the quality of a good silvertip badger brush, it blows the Escali out of the water in performance and is surprisingly cheap. There is a break in period, and once you&#x27;re through that, you will have a fine brush that will be much softer and will build a much better lather than the Escali ever will. There are two main brands that make very good boar hair brushes that can be purchased in the $10-25 range, and those are Omega and Semogue.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Where do I find a boar hair brush?     <li> Like double-edge razors, badger brushes have a finite life.  Still, you expect the finer - and more expensive - brushes to last longer. The quality of bristles appears to be the same as brushes that go for more than twice the price.  (Are there different grades of badger fur, I wonder?)  This brush has held its shape and firmness, stimulating to the skin without being harsh or prickly.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The handle is made of wood and, while finished with lacquer (or varnish), care must be taken to properly dry the brush so the handle does not get soaked, dried out, and cracked; stone or plastic handles are generally preferable in this regard, but the Escali brush has held up well.  Indeed, by the time this one wears out, I would feel that the full value of the product - and beyond - had been realized. Well, I am not sure about that one but universally the silvertip is regarded as the best and usually what you desire for most faces unless you have just such a tough face that a plain badger will do. I have seen some decent ones around $50 to as high as $300 + for a single silvertip badger brush!!!  Here is a tip though...........if you dislike the badger on this brush you can replace the knot with a silvertip for most times cheaper than buying the entire brush with handle.     <li> This was the first brush I purchased when I started wetshaving. Starting with the first time I used the brush, and continuing up to the present, stray hairs began coming out. Some days it would be just a couple, others easily a half dozen or more. But I was saved from having to deal with that potential issue by another one. The handle fell off the brush. I had only been using it for a month, and had been careful not to use it roughly, but it still happened. I uploaded two photos, and of them is a closeup of the glue used to hold the bristles and handle together. Instead of filling the entire area between the two, which would have produced a strong bond, the glue had a large hole in it. This allowed water to seep in and erode it away until the brush fell apart. Considering how these are mass produced somewhere, I highly doubt this is an isolated incident. Perhaps others are more fortunate and it takes them longer than a month for the brush to fall apart, but I have no doubt that eventually it will happen. So do yourself a favor, and buy something else.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The [[ASIN:B000G647Y8 Tweezerman  Men&#x27;s Shaving Brush]] is actually cheaper than the Escali, and I&#x27;ve heard very good things about it both on amazon and sites devoted to wetshaving, so that is a very good alternative. The lowest is this one, the \\&quot;pure badger\\&quot; one. Next comes \\&quot;best badger,\\&quot; and the most expensive one is \\&quot;silvertip badger.\\&quot; The difference is in what parts of the badger the hairs come from, with pure badger brushes considered the roughest, and silvertip ones the softest. Best badger brushes are considered a good medium for those that like the luxurious softness of the silvertip, but still want the bristles to have enough strength to build a good lather or exfoliate the face.and buy a best badger quality brush. Oh, well, their Bubba beer coolers are full.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Those that complain about some of the hair coming out of it need to learn to break it in. Nothing more, nothing less. When you get the brush take it out of the package, put it in your right and, stick you left index finger out, and then slap the brush 10 or 12 times up and down against that finger.     <li> This little brush works wonders creating a nice lather for your face.    People have mentioned bristles falling out. That has not happened to me at all and I only recently went back to shaving with a non-electric razor.    Some things to note on keeping this product in good condition:    1) Do not let water leak into the handle  2) Do not be overly rough with it  3) Rinse the bristles thoroughly to get all foam out of them (I use a medium-hot water -- aka it doesn&#x27;t hurt your hand when you touch it)  4) When storing this product, make sure that it is pointing bristles-DOWN so that any remaining water will drip OUT of it    Now, #4 may seem like a hard task if you don&#x27;t have a brush holder. You may not want to even buy one. I know I didn&#x27;t, but that&#x27;s where some DIY comes in.    Some people use a coat hanger to hang this product from somewhere in their bathroom. That works pretty well.    I on the other hand, did not have a coat hanger for some reason to spare. So what I did was -- I used the box it came in (a plastic, see-through container). This small, plastic box has a hole near the top that you often see on products so that they can hang from walls in stores. I attached a paper clip to this part and am now simply letting it hang from a spot in my bathroom. That&#x27;s even less work than using a coat hanger! If you do it this way, then you may want to poke a small hole or two in the plastic as well so that moisture can escape. Just some FYI for those who want to DIY! (was that as catchy as it sounded in my head? oh boy do I hope so!)    EDIT: I have added an image to the gallery that shows my &#x27;DIY&#x27;. As you can see, I have something in my bathroom that is perfect for hanging things with a paper clip. You can use other things though, such as string, Rubber Bands, etc. Hope it helps!    EDIT (11/21/2014): I bought this ages ago and it still works like a champ! However, the bristles now ARE falling out (every shave). There&#x27;s so many of them that it just doesn&#x27;t matter, but they do get in the sink and on your face. Not a big deal really (especially considering the price of this product).</li>

Reading other reviews I expected to see some bristles falling out the first couple times I used it, and I wasn&#x27;t disappointed.  The first maybe 10 times I lathered up, I would lose 2-3 bristles each time.  I also noticed the distinct \\&quot;animal\\&quot; smell some other users reported the first couple times I used it.  Honestly, this is not a huge deal.  I still got a wonderful lather with very little effort and the animal smell is long gone.  If the animal smell turns you off, don&#x27;t buy a product made from the hair of an animal.    The important thing to remember is that you have to care for this product correctly.  Rinse it out VERY well BEFORE you use it for the first time.  Also, if you put it away wet with soap still in it, the brush won&#x27;t last as long for you.  Rinse it out and flick the water out of it when you&#x27;re done and it will last.  I&#x27;ve had mine for over a year of daily use and I don&#x27;t have any intentions of getting another one because I simply don&#x27;t need to yet. Although at less than $15, I won&#x27;t hesitate to buy this same brush again when I have to.    Those that complain about this brush and say \\&quot;you get what you pay for\\&quot; must be used to spending (wasting) a ton of money on an expensive, top-of-the-line silver tipped badger brush. I&#x27;m not knocking you if you have that kind of cash to throw around on frivolous luxuries, but if you&#x27;re a working class guy like me, with 3 kids and a mortgage, I promise you won&#x27;t be disappointed with this brush.  You&#x27;ll get a better, more comfortable shave lathering up with a brush than you do with that canned s*** foam and your hand.  This brush is priced similar to boar&#x27;s hair brushes, which are ALL crap, so don&#x27;t torture your skin by trying to save a few nickels by buying one of them.    To summarize, this brush is WELL worth the small investment.  With proper care it will last you quite some time, all while giving you a great shaving experience.  I would also recommend that, while you&#x27;re shopping for shaving gear on Amazon, grab some good quality shaving soap or cream.  It makes a big difference.</li>
